answer_html: This would probably be seasonal fluctuations, so it would be \(c_{n}\) for about 12 months.
answer_latex:
This would probably be seasonal fluctuations, so it
would be $c_{n}$ for about 12 months.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Since \(c_{n}\) is a complex number with real and imaginary part, we write \(c_{n}\) in its complex exponential form

\(c_{n}\) = \(\left |c _n{} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n} }\)

Therefore \(c_{n}\) reflects the original temperature function\(^{\prime}\)s frequency spectrum. If we put the above expression back into the Fourier series representation of y(t), we have

\(y(t)=\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n}}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i(\omega _{n}t+\phi _{n})}\)

t=0 or t=T would make \(c_{n}\) the largest. Because both t=0 and t=T would make \(e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t}\) = 1. So \(c_{0}\) and \(c_{T}\) have the largest absolute value.

The values of \(c_{n}\) might you expect to have the largest absolute value is the frequency for the maximum temperature swings over the course of years. This would probably be seasonal fluctuations, so it would be \(c_{n}\) for about 12 months.
sols_latex:
Since $c_{n}$ is a complex number with real and imaginary part, we write
$c_{n}$ in its complex exponential form

$c_{n}$ = $\left |c _n{} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n} }$

Therefore $c_{n}$ reflects the original temperature function$^{\prime}$s
frequency spectrum. If we put the above expression back into the Fourier
series representation of y(t), we have

$y(t)=\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n}}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i(\omega _{n}t+\phi _{n})}$

t=0 or t=T would make $c_{n}$ the largest. Because both t=0 and t=T
would make $e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t}$ = 1. So $c_{0}$ and $c_{T}$ have the
largest absolute value.

The values of $c_{n}$ might you expect to have the largest absolute
value is the frequency for the maximum temperature swings over the
course of years. This would probably be seasonal fluctuations, so it
would be $c_{n}$ for about 12 months.
sols_raw:
Since <math>c_{n}</math> is a complex number with real and imaginary part, we write <math>c_{n}</math> in its complex exponential form

<math>c_{n}</math> = <math>\left |c _n{} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n} }</math>

Therefore <math>c_{n}</math> reflects the original temperature function’s frequency spectrum. If we put the above expression back into the Fourier series representation of y(t), we have

<math>y(t)=\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i\phi _{n}}e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t} = \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }\left | c_{n} \right |e^{2\pi i(\omega _{n}t+\phi _{n})}</math>


t=0 or t=T would make <math>c_{n}</math> the largest. Because both t=0 and t=T would make <math>e^{2\pi i\frac{n}{T}t}</math> = 1. So <math>c_{0}</math> and <math>c_{T}</math> have the largest absolute value.

The values of <math>c_{n}</math> might you expect to have the largest absolute value is the frequency for the maximum temperature swings over the course of years. This would probably be seasonal fluctuations, so it would be <math>c_{n}</math> for about 12 months.
statement_html: Explain the physical significance of the values \(|c_n|\) and how these relate to \(\omega_n\). If t is measure in days, and the time period T encompasses several years, which values of cn might you expect to be the largest absolute value? (Think about what time scales you expect temperature to fluctuate over.)
statement_latex:
Explain the physical significance of the values $|c_n|$ and how these
relate to $\omega_n$. If \emph{t} is measure in days, and the time
period \emph{T} encompasses several years, which values of
\emph{c\textsubscript{n}} might you expect to be the largest absolute
value? \emph{(Think about what time scales you expect temperature to
fluctuate over.)}
statement_raw: Explain the physical significance of the values <math>|c_n|</math> and how these relate to <math>\omega_n</math>. If ''t'' is measure in days, and the time period ''T'' encompasses several years, which values of ''c<sub>n</sub>'' might you expect to be the largest absolute value? ''(Think about what time scales you expect temperature to fluctuate over.)''
